sub_title: Advanced Concept Development Engineer at Boston Scientific
summary:
Currently working as a Concept Engineer at Boston Scientific and contributing to the development of novel features of the Rhythmia mapping system.

Previously working as a research scientist at EPD Solutions - Philips to develop novel mapping tools for the KODEX-EPD system.

Previously working as a research scientist at IHU-LIRYC to develop signal processing tools to treat and understand atrial and ventricular arrhythmias from body surface and intracardiac signals.

Previously working at Brigham and Women's Hospital as a postdoctoral fellow for cardiac electrophysiology, with particular focus on arrhythmias. Specialties: ECG and action potential analysis, patch-clamp techniques.

Previously working for a Phd project focusing on surface ECG processing for the treatment of persistent atrial fibrillation by RF catheter ablation, based on advanced statistics and classification techniques.

Past experience as a biomedical engineer working on medical image description and automatic classification.

Past experience in image processing and computer science for automatic analysis of IFA (Immunofluorescence Assays) equipment and design of an IFA microscope (lighting and sinking systems, image acquisition software).

Cultural background focused on monitoring and projecting biomedical devices. Interested in research applications in signal and image processing. ECG processing and  cellular voltage-clamp techniques.

Specialties: VB, Matlab, image processing, C++, Php (Basic level); computer networking, ability to assemble a computer system (Windows 2000 server and Linux) and install an operating system, network troubleshooting (certified by Cisco Systems: IT Essentials II level), automatic process monitoring by PLC and basic knowledge of SCADA systems; good written and oral English (certifications by Cambridge University: PET, FCE); fluent French

International journal reviewer: Eurasip, Biomedical Signal Processing and Control, Computers in Biology and Medicine, Annals of Biomedical Engineering. International conference reviewer: MEDICON, ICBEB, Cinc.

Cinc 2014 and 2015 Local Committee member.

Multidimensional characterization of ECG in persistent atrial fibrillation

Description
Atrial fibrillation is the most common cardiac arrhythmia inducing a disorganized generation of electrical signals in the atria, and consequently increasing the risk of drawbacks such as infarct and ictus.
Radiofrequency catheter ablation is becoming one of the most popular therapies for the treatment of the disease. Yet inconsistent success rates are being reported from different centers practicing the therapy because of its unpredictability and clinicians' subjectivity.
The present project aims at the development of signal processing techniques to achieve a more careful selection of persistent AF patients who may actually benefit from ablation.
Furthermore, it will allow to reduce risks, costs and treatment duration, as well as overcoming limitations of current techniques (e.g. too elementary features or signal variability over time and over multiple leads) by a non-invasive approach.
Consequently, surface electrocardiogram (ECG) and its spatial complexity will be processed by applying suitable decomposition techniques (PCA, BSS), executing advanced automatic classification algorithms and searching for new combinations of parameters.
